Award.AwardTitle: CC* Compute: Deep Bayou: Accelerating Scientific Discoveries with A GPU Cluster

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: Modern science increasingly relies on high performance computing (HPC) and data analytics to make discoveries about our world. In recent years, graphics processing units (GPUs), a specialty computer hardware originally developed for graphic applications with a unique, highly parallel architecture, has become a key enabling technology for both types of workloads. Through this project, Louisiana State University (LSU) expands its existing computing facilities with the addition of Deep Bayou, a GPU cluster consisting of 12 compute nodes and 26 NVIDIA GPU devices.<br/><br/>The initial research projects enabled by Deep Bayou include particle physics, gravitational wave source characterization with LIGO, ocean and ocean-atmosphere modeling, bioinformatics, infrastructure modeling for disaster management, material sciences, computational biology, and fundamental GPU architecture design. The Deep Bayou infrastructure and organization is also open to additional initiatives and projects through an application process. In addition to researchers across LSU campus, the project partners with the Open Science Grid (OSG) to share the GPU resources among the research community across the nation. Deep Bayou will make a significant contribution to the building of future HPC workforce, as many training and education activities plan to leverage its availability. Through existing state- and federal-sponsored programs such as Louisiana Optical Network Infrastructure (LONI), Baton Rouge: Bringing Youth Technology, Education and Success (BRBYTES) and Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU), K-12 students and undergraduates can have access to courses and workshops facilitated on the cluster, many of whom are from underrepresented minority communities.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Artificial intelligence, or AI, is an emerging technology that is transforming research in every scientific discipline. Leveraging machine learning algorithms such as deep neural networks, AI allows us to make scientific discovery and find solutions much faster than or even impossible through traditional methods. The applications of AI on Deep Bayou range from personalized cancer care to automated housing design, as well as better understanding on Alzheimer's disease, find suitable biomaterial for cardiac repair, more accurate and efficient of ocean modelling, and the next generation computer architecture.

Deep Bayou also makes a significant contribution to building a skilled workforce for the future. Through the scientific computing boot camps sponsored by Louisiana Optical Network Infrastructure and Louisiana Biomedical Research Networks, and the weekly training classes offered by LSU HPC, hundreds of graduate and undergraduate students have had the opportunity to practice programing with Python and R, as well as deep learning basics. Many of them were from minority-serving and underrepresented institutions. In the previous two summers, Deep Bayou was used by the Research Experiences of Undergraduate program at LSU to develop and run their codes when they worked on computational science projects under the supervision of the faculty members and research staff at the Center for Computational and Technology at LSU. Many of these students will go to graduate school focusing on computational disciplines.
